urn:contentItem:5TBY-70Y1-JC65-516C-00000-00A US privacy law could be good for Google - but bad for you2018-09-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:16:36ZLexisNexisBUSINESS NEWSA US privacy law could be good for Google - but bad for youBy MARCY GORDON and MATT O'BRIENAssociated PressWASHINGTON

WASHINGTON (AP) - Congress is taking the first steps toward setting national rules governing how companies use consumers data - although one of its goals might be to prevent states from enacting stronger privacy protections of their own.

The approach being pondered by policymakers and pushed by the internet industry leans toward a relatively light government touch. That's in contrast to stricter European rules that took effect in May and a California law that takes effect in 2020. Other states are also considering more aggressive protections.

However it works out, any regulatory push will find it challenging to reconcile the concerns of privacy advocates who want people to have more control over the use of their personal data - where they've been, what they view, who their friends are -and the powerful companies who mine that information for profit.

During a Senate hearing Wednesday, several Democratic senators warned that a national law could simply be used to override state efforts. Calling that pre-emption the "Holy Grail" for the industry, Democratic Sen. Brian Schatz of Hawaii said it won't get the bipartisan support it needs if the goal is merely to replace California's law with a weaker, "non-progressive" federal statute.

Senior executives from AT&T, Amazon, Apple, Google, Twitter and Charter Communications all told senators that they support a federal proposal that could negate "inconsistent" state privacy laws. Facebook, which faced a major congressional grilling over privacy back in April, was not present at the hearing.

Apple, which doesn't rely on advertising for revenue, was the most vocal in support of a stronger federal law. Bud Tribble, Apple's vice president of software technology, said the bar would have to be "high enough in the federal legislation" to provide meaningful consumer protections.

The Senate Commerce Committee hearing comes amid increasing anxiety over safeguarding consumers' data online and recent scandals that have stoked outrage among users and politicians. The committee's chairman, Republican Sen. John Thune of South Dakota, said both Republicans and Democrats now want to reach consensus on a national privacy law that "will help consumers, promote innovation, reward organizations with little to hide and force shady practitioners to clean up their act."

An early move in President Donald Trump's tenure set the tone on data privacy. He signed a bill into law in April 2017 that allows internet providers to sell information about their customers' browsing habits. The legislation scrapped Obama-era online privacy rules aimed at giving consumers more control over how broadband companies like AT&T, Comcast and Verizon share that information.

Allie Bohm, policy counsel at the consumer group Public Knowledge, said examples abound of companies not only using the data to market products but also to profile consumers and restrict who sees their offerings: African Americans not getting access to ads for housing, minorities and older people excluded from seeing job postings.

What is needed, privacy advocates maintain, is legislation to govern the entire "life cycle" of consumers' data: how it's collected, used, kept, shared and sold.

The 28-nation European Union put in strict new rules this spring that require companies to justify why they're collecting and using personal data gleaned from phones, apps and visited websites. Companies also must give EU users the ability to access and delete data, and to object to data use under one of the claimed reasons.

A similar law in California will compel companies to tell customers upon request what personal data they've collected, why it was collected and what types of third parties have received it. Companies will be able to offer discounts to customers who allow their data to be sold and to charge those who opt out a reasonable amount, based on how much the company makes selling the information.

Andrew DeVore, Amazon's vice president and associate general counsel, told the Senate panel Wednesday that it should consider the "possible unintended consequences" of California's approach. For instance, he said the state law defines personal information too broadly such that it could include all data.

The California law doesn't take effect until 2020 and applies only to California consumers, but it could have fallout effects on other states. And it's strong enough to have rattled Big Tech, which is seeking a federal data-privacy law that would be more lenient toward the industry.

"A national privacy framework should be consistent throughout all states, pre-empting state consumer-privacy and data security laws," the Internet Association said in a recent statement . The group represents about 40 big internet and tech companies, spanning Airbnb and Amazon to Zillow. "A strong national baseline creates clear rules for companies."

The Trump White House said this summer that the administration is working on it, meeting with companies and other interested parties.

The goal is a policy "that is the appropriate balance between privacy and prosperity," White House spokeswoman Lindsay Walters said. "We look forward to working with Congress on a legislative solution."

___

Matt O'Brien reported from Providence, Rhode Island.

urn:contentItem:5WPD-HPN1-JCMN-Y060-00000-00A US senator has introduced a bill that would stop Facebook, Twitter, or YouTube from endlessly showing you content, in an attempt to keep users from getting addicted to social media2019-07-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:16:36ZLexisNexisA US senator has introduced a bill that would stop Facebook, Twitter, or YouTube from endlessly showing you content, in an attempt to keep users from getting addicted to social mediaKevin Webb

Jul 30, 2019( The Business Insider: http://www.businessinsider.com/ Delivered by Newstex) Reuters US Senator Josh Hawley[1] has introduced a new bill intended to help protect social media users from forming addictive habits. The Social Media Addiction Reduction Technology Act[2] would prevent social media platforms like Facebook, YouTube, Twitter, or Snapchat from using features that automatically generate an endless stream of content. The bill would also require social media companies to add an automatic time limit of 30 minutes per day for all users (though users could change it), and inform users of how much time they have spent on the platform every 30 minutes. Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories.[3] US Senator Josh Hawley (R-MO) has introduced a new bill intended intended to regulate the way that users interact with social media, the latest in a series of proposed legislation aimed at major tech companies.[4] The Social Media Addiction Reduction Technology Act would fundamentally change the way that social media platforms like Facebook, YouTube, Twitter, and Snapchat engage with users, and call greater attention to how much time users are spending on each platform.

"The business model for many internet companies, especially social media companies, is to capture as much of their users' attention as possible," reads the bill, in part.[5] "To achieve this end, some of the internet companies design their platforms and services to exploit brain physiology and human psychology. By exploiting psychological and physiological vulnerabilities, these design choices interfere with the free choice of users." If enacted into law, the bill would require social media companies to limit the amount of automatically generated content shown to users, and prevent videos from automatically playing without user approval. Facebook and Twitter can surface a nearly endless stream of content to users as they scroll through their timeline or pursue trending topics. These platforms also allow videos to start playing automatically as soon as a user scrolls by.Tweet Embed: //twitter.com/mims/statuses/1156196153463123969?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw Senator Hawley: "Big tech has embraced a business model of addiction. Too much of the 'innovation' in this space is designed not to create better products, but to capture more attention by using psychological tricks that make it difficult to look away."YouTube has also been criticized for its use of autoplay. After a user watches a video, the platform will continually surface other videos related to the user's original choice. However, reports have indicated that autoplay can also lead users to increasingly controversial or radical videos, as the algorithm selects new video to watch. Earlier this year The Verge reported[6] that watching certain videos featuring children would lead users to multiple videos featuring moments of children involving nudity or other compromising activities that could be deemed as sexual. Read more: Facebook and YouTube could be held responsible for the toxic swamp of content on their platforms under an explosive new bill[7] Along with new restrictions on how content is displayed, the Social Media Addiction Reduction Technology Act would require social media companies to introduce daily and weekly time limits. The bill calls for an automatic time limit of 30 minutes per day, though users would be able to adjust the amount of time for themselves. However, social media platforms would also be required to show a notification telling the user how much time they've spent on the platform that day, displayed at least once every half hour. The Social Media Addiction Reduction Technology Act would also prevent social media companies from rewarding users for prolonged engagement with their platforms. For example, Snapchat promotes user Snapstreaks, which track how many days in a row a user has sent pictures to the same person. YouTube awards users with badges for being a paid subscriber to certain channels for six months or more, with badges becoming more rare as their time as a paid subscriber increases. Enforcement of the bill would fall under the purview of the Federal Trade Commission and the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The FTC would be required to provide a report on internet addiction and how social media affects psychology every three years. If approved, the bill would allow the commission to fine social media companies for non-compliance as well. Sen. Hawley has been vocal in his criticism of social media[8] and major technology companies since taking office at the start of the year. The Republican senator has repeatedly accused social media and video games of using addiction to fuel engagement.[9]The Social Media Addiction Reduction Technology Act does not share any co-sponsors and hasn't reached the committee stage yet.NOW WATCH: I cleaned my entire apartment with 4 of Amazon's highest-rated cleaning robots, but I could've done a much better job myself[10]See Also: How to delete or deactivate your Snapchat account, which you can only do from a desktop browser[11]Lil Nas X demanded an edit button and was taught how to meditate by Jack Dorsey during a goofy stunt as Twitter's 'CEO for the day'[12]Facebook's regulatory woes are now affecting 'the fundamental business in ways we haven't seen before,' analyst warns[13] SEE ALSO:Facebook and YouTube could be held Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5VHT-X1S1-JBJ7-N13P-00000-00Aussie in middle of global tax tussle2019-02-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:16:36ZLexisNexisAussie in middle of global tax tussleJohn Kehoe

As the OECD works on the biggest global tax shake-up in more than 50 years, Australian expat David Bradbury is at the forefront of efforts to avoid an international tax war.

When Australian expat and international tax diplomat David Bradbury hosts business meetings in Paris, he is often surrounded by counterparts from titans of the world economy who spar over how to tax multinational companies.

As the head of tax policy at the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, Bradbury has been at the negotiating table with executives from Silicon Valley technology giants, President Donald Trump's US Treasury, European firms and bureaucrats, and occasionally counterparts from Canberra.

Bradbury - a former Sydney-based corporate tax lawyer and minister in the Rudd and Gillard Labor governments - is at the epicentre of a global tussle over the taxation of the rapidly emerging digital economy.

The OECD is trying to pull off the biggest global tax shake-up in more than 50 years. Such is the magnitude of the job, Bradbury - as the head of the OECD's digital economy taskforce secretariat - was named in December by by the International Tax Review as the equal-most influential person in global tax.

In an interview with The Australian Financial Review, Bradbury says from Paris that the potential global tax reforms could "redefine who has taxing rights in a way that is even more profound" than originally envisaged by world leaders when they set up the project. For the past six years the OECD's Base Erosion and Profit Shifting (BEPS) project has had a big focus on how to collect more tax from digital firms such as America's so-called FAANG companies: Facebook, Apple, Amazon, Netflix and Alphabet's Google.

In the data-rich modern economy, tech giants have sometimes tried to avoid having a physical presence (in tax jargon known as a permanent establishment) in jurisdictions in order to pay minimal tax in lucrative developed markets like Europe and Australia.

How to tax the provision of online advertising by Facebook and Google, Amazon's cloud services and advertising, and subscription and freemium streaming services by Netflix and Spotify is a vexed issue for tax authorities around the world. With American tech and other intellectual property-intensive darlings in the firing line, the Obama and Trump administrations have bitten back.

The US is concerned anti-American forces in Europe are attempting a revenue heist and regulatory attacks on Silicon Valley giants at the expense of Uncle Sam. There has been a stalemate on forging international consensus on taxing the digital economy after the US last year effectively vetoed proposals.

Surprise twist

Yet in a surprise twist, the global tax debate was recently turned on its head. Trump's top Treasury international tax official, former PwC and Baker McKenzie tax adviser Chip Harter, offered an olive branch to other countries. The US may be prepared to do a deal on global tax.

The Trump administration argues the vulnerabilities in the global tax base are not limited to highly digital firms but are more widespread for intangible assets owned by the likes of McDonald's, Starbucks and Nike. The American quid pro quo is that the original BEPS project be expanded beyond the digital economy to the rules on taxing IP and intangible assets more broadly.

Under the US proposal, a larger share of the profits would be taxed where a product is consumed - potentially delivering valuable revenue to big consumer markets like the US which has a population of 330 million people. The proposal grapples with a much more fundamental allocation of taxing rights between countries than BEPS originally envisaged.

"It's potentially bigger than the BEPS project because it would redefine who has taxing rights," Bradbury says.

The 127 members of BEPS in January agreed to examine proposals involving two pillars that might form the basis of a long-term consensus. The first pillar focuses on the allocation of taxing rights between countries and the second pillar addresses other BEPS issues.

"Under the first pillar, which focuses on the allocation of taxing rights among countries, several proposals have been made that would allocate more taxing rights to market-user jurisdictions in the case of highly digitalised firms," Bradbury says. "These proposals would require a reconsideration of existing transfer pricing rules and contemplate solutions that go beyond the arm's length principle - which has been the key principle underpinning the transfer pricing rules.

"The second pillar will consider granting new taxing rights that would strengthen the ability of jurisdictions to tax profits where other jurisdictions with taxing rights apply a low effective tax rate to those profits."

Opinions diverge widely between the big economies on how to proceed. The US wants to allocate some of the residual profit from intangibles to the consumer market, such as the US. The United Kingdom is keen to expand the taxing rights on big tech firms but wants to restrain the advancement into other industries that might hit its own multinationals.

The UK is also less interested in taxing where the "consumer" is, and is keener on taxing where the "user" is. For example, a "user" of a digital platform may upload photos, make social media posts or sign up friends to a service, without paying any money. Though they are technically not a "consumer", arguably these users add value to the digital company, even if no money changes hands.

To complicate matters, the Germans and French believe if the system is going to move beyond taxing digital firms, then a global minimum corporate tax should be imposed - a change the US corporate tax reforms in 2016 effectively imposed on US-headquartered multinationals.

Uphill task

Bradbury is in the thick of all this. To be sure, the OECD working on behalf of the Group of 20 world leaders faces an uphill task to finalise a compromise by a deadline of 2020.

With impatient governments in Australia and the UK rolling out a range of unilateral tax laws to hit multinational tax avoidance, tax experts are worried a failure to achieve a breakthrough could lead to an international tax war. Some others argue unilateral action by Australia may encourage countries to work out a global solution.

Bradbury, who as a Labor assistant treasurer did some of the early work on Australia's multinational tax-avoidance laws, is diplomatic. "Australia has been closely engaged in this work and this will be increasingly important as we move into the next phase of deliberations," he says.

Many private-sector tax advisers believe the OECD's task is nigh on impossible, given the intractable political fight over how to carve up the global tax pie.

"It is hard to see how the OECD will be able to achieve a consensus by 2020 and if they don't I think we will see more unilateral measures becoming permanent," says Clayton Utz tax partner Niv Tadmore. "That would create ambiguity and incoherence in the international tax system."

Bradbury won't concede he has the impossible in front of him. In fact, the father of four teenage students recently signed a three-year contract extension at the OECD in Paris, which would take him to eight years in total in the job. He is deeply ensconced in Parisian life, musing that his bilingual children are much more fluent in French than he.

Politics still part of the job

It's a long way for the former western Sydney MP from the time he climbed aboard a patrol boat in Darwin with then-prime minister Julia Gillard to showcase his border security credentials before the 2010 election. Despite recent rumours of a potential return to local politics, Bradbury shows little interest in resuming a Canberra political life. However, he admits politics is still part of the job at the OECD.

"We are trying to achieve consensus with 127 jurisdictions at the table, all contributing on an equal footing," he says. "Our work is not like a parliament where you need 50 per cent plus one. You need to understand the various interests and perspectives of countries in order to understand where they are coming from.

"That requires an even greater understanding of the positions of the countries and national interests. It's a technical exercise but also a political one."

In comparison to a breakdown in multilateralism on trade and immigration, Bradbury at least thinks tax has the potential underpinnings for a deal.

"At a time when there seems to be almost complete intractability on so many global issues, this seems to be one area where countries are constructively engaging with a strong desire to make progress," he says.

"In my experience there is a pretty strong degree of political will among countries to try to address these issues. Where that leads us in the next couple of years remains to be seen."
